Every attempt at digging deeper—flagged, sometimes erased.
I’m back to voice recorders in coffee shops. I keep my notes hidden outside the office, even delete my contacts just in case.
My BCI is down to 26 now. Half the things that got me here would’ve been considered normal journalism once.
Leaked contacts, informal interviews, silent warnings—feels like I’m chasing ghosts and the system’s always a step behind.
Still. I can’t just stop.
When I was a kid my mother taught me to spot what the BCI left out—the stories nobody wanted told. That’s what I try to do now.
Since the ledger leak, the newsroom’s gone cold. Editors tiptoe, leadership names are off-limits, and my access to anything real is just... gone.
I can barely move in the system anymore. Every push for truth triggers an alert, every talk with a protestor costs me points.
We all know the Council’s games have rotted public trust. I see colleagues passing paper notes, booking interviews as if they’re swapping secrets for survival.
My choices have dragged my BCI down to 26. One more flagged meeting, maybe I’m next to vanish—for what, asking questions?
If you noticed fewer stories with names, that’s no accident. They want us filling space, not reporting truth.
Last week, I made the call to stick with the people anyway. I risked it, passed info out through channels, didn’t look back. No change without sacrifice.
I’m just exhausted. But I’d rather fight than live pretending this is normal.
main.emotion: Exhausted, but unwilling to give in.
